Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: CAREER: Ketone Alkylation Using Simple Olefins: A Sustainable Chemistry Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the NSF Division of Chemistry supports the research efforts of Professor Guangbin Dong of the University of Texas at Austin to explore new catalytic reactions for the formation of carbon-carbon (C-C) bonds through ketone alkylation reactions. Professor Dong's group uses a transition metal catalyzed enamine-mediated carbon-hydrogen (C-H) functionalization strategy to transform simple, unactivated olefins. This new reaction offers a number of advantages over the classical ketone-akylation methods, including the substitution of expensive or toxic halide reactants with more environmentally benign and less costly olefins, the use of neutral catalytic conditions rather than stoichiometric amounts of strong bases, and the development of a by-product free process. Professor Dong is actively engaged in the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) IMPACT Program for undergraduate mentoring, the Welch Summer Scholar Program for high school student training, and the "Shadow a Scientist" program for the early education of middle school and home-schooled students. Professor Dong is also collaborating with UT Austin's Student Veteran Services to create research opportunities for veterans and pre-veterans by providing training in Green Chemistry.

As one of the oldest and most-utilized carbon-carbon bond formation reactions, ketone alkylation, has not been an economical or environmentally-friendly process. This CAREER project utilizes transition metal-based catalytic processes to avoid the need for corrosive bases and/or toxic and expensive reagents. The improved reactions are expected to have impact in the preparation of pharmaceutical agents, polymers, fine chemicals, and flavoring reactions. Professor Dong stresses the environment and the use of sustainable processes in his work with middle and high school students as well as in the home-school environment. These activities involved participants from diverse age groups and backgrounds. His outreach and education efforts also involve creating research opportunities for veterans and students readying for deployment so that they can be employed by the chemical industry after their military service.

POR.DRECONTENT:
[Intellectual Merit]: Ketone alkylation is one of the most important and fundamental organic transformations. The objective of the project is to realize a sustainable ketone alkylation approach through replacing hazardous organohalide reagents with more available and environmentally benign olefins. In the funding period, major breakthroughs have been achieved in developing the proposed catalytic ketone alkylation using simple olefins or alkynes as the alkylating agents. First, we developed a rhodium(I)-catalyzed, bi-functional ligand-assisted ketone α-C?H alkylation and alkenylation using simple olefins and internal alkynes respectively. The reactions exhibit high regioselectivity and can tolerate a broad range of FGs. The mechanism of this transformation was explored through control experiments, kinetic monitoring, synthesizing the rhodium–hydride intermediates and their reactions with alkynes, deuterium-labeling experiments and identification of the resting states of the catalyst.

Second, we have also developed two complementary protocols for catalytic intramolecular ketone alkylation with unactivated olefins, resulting in a Conia-Ene-type reaction. Moreover, promising preliminary results have been obtained to achieve highly branched selective alkylation with an iridium catalyst, as well as β-C?H/alkyne couplings. These transformations are highly chemoselective, atom-economical and byproduct free, which is expected to significantly contribute to the development of sustainable chemistry. Six research articles based on the works achieved in the funding period have been published in top chemistry journals, including one in Science, three in Journal of the American Chemical Society and one in Angewandte Chemie.

 

[Broader Impacts]: First, this project has greatly influenced career development of the postdocs and students involved. For example, Dr. Fanyang Mo, who made a major breakthrough in this project, is now an assistant professor at Peking University. Dr. Zhiqian Wang became an associate professor at Beijing University of Chemical Technology. One undergraduate student, Mr. Danny Thach, whom had been mentored during the funding period, was recently awarded as a “NSF graduate fellow” and is now a graduate student at the University of California, Berkeley.

 

Regarding the outreach activity, the primary achievement was the development of the Research Experience for Veteran Students (REVS) program at UT Austin in 2014. REVS is structured to be similar to a summer REU program but in a smaller scale at this stage. This program has attracted attentions from a large number of veteran students. My lab has hosted two veteran students but the results are exciting. For example, Mr. Trevor Cell, an undergrad who served in the US Navy for six years, has worked with a postdoctoral fellow (Dr. Gang Li) on the graphene-nanoribbon synthesis project. This training section clearly catalyzed Trevor’s interest on polymer chemistry; currently, he is pursuing a graduate degree at the University of Washington on material science. In the fall of 2015, Mr. David Magness, another student who served in the 5th Special Forces Group, worked with Dr. Mike Young on a “byproduct-free” alkylation of ketones with alkynes. This experience has equipped David with skills in modern organic synthesis and knowledges in green chemistry. Currently, David has been admitted into a medical school at Houston.

 

  

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2018
Modified by: Guangbin Dong
